title: Ashhurst residents making a difference for children in Fiji
text:
Ashhurst residents making a difference for children in Fiji GEORGIA FORRESTER Last updated 19:39, October 13 2015 David Unwin/ Fairfax NZ 
Ashhurst residents Mara Whitten, left, and Shelley Bishop, hold up a signed Fijian flag they received following their holiday-cum-good will mission to Fiji. 
When two Ashhurst residents booked a five-day holiday to Fiji, they planned to spend their time kicking-back by the resort pool and relaxing. 
Instead Mara Whitten and Shelley Bishop spent their September holiday helping school children in a Fijian village called Vitogo. 
Dental assistant Mara Whitten said they had wanted to explore parts of Fiji which were outside the normal tourist hot-spots. Supplied 
Bishop, left, and Whitten donating clothing to Fijian school principal, Marth, in Vitogo. 
"We wanted to see the other side of Fiji - all the bad stuff as well. 
"We chose to visit a local village and we just fell in love with the children there," she said. 
They took over five bags of clothing which their own children had grown out of. 
The two Palmerston North mothers said they were shocked by the little amount of clothing and toys the Fijian children had. 
Whitten hopes to create a scheme to regularly send clothing, toys and school necessities over to Vitogo. 
"The plan is to collect as much as we can and take it all over there." 
"We want children's books, shoes, pencils, hats, glasses - just school things which every child needs. Ad Feedback 
"Even the basics like nappies and bras are needed. All the small things in life that we take for granted," she said. 
Whitten hopes to donate the goods to the school and eventually head over to Fiji herself, to teach English and sport. 
"I want to get people to donate the things they simply throw out so we can help enhance the learning of others." 
Whitten, who was a founder of Smiling Straight Dental Trust in the Manawatu region, said the tooth decay some of the Fijian children had was "truly shocking". 
Moving to Fiji to assist volunteer dental work could be something to work towards in the future, she said. 
She hopes to head back to Fiji before March next year and take over as much clothing and school tools for the children as possible. 
Bartender Shelley Bishop said her experience in Fiji was a "real eye opener". 
Vitogo's school had about 200 children which ran from kindergarten to year eight. 
There was a big sports field in front of the school, but the children had no toys or balls to kick around, Bishop said. 
"I was a little bit heartbroken to see the kids running around with no shoes on." 
Bishop said members of the Ashhurst community had already donated four boxes of toys to send to Fiji.
